docs.title: 🥒 DLL Pickle
docs.text: A PowerShell module that helps you get un-stuck from dependency version conflicts that can occur when connecting to multiple Microsoft online services.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Any of the following PowerShell editions:

  • PowerShell on Linux, macOS, or Windows
  • Windows PowerShell 5.1

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Install-Module DLLPickle -Scope CurrentUser

Or, if you use Microsoft.PowerShell.PSResourceGet, run:

Install-PSResource -Name DLLPickle -Prerelease

docs.title: Using
docs.text:
All you have to do to use DLL Pickle is import it and run the Import-DPLibrary command. (This function will be done automatically during the module import process before the v1.0 release!)

Import-Module DLLPickle
Import-DPLibrary

This will automatically import the newest versions of the Microsoft Authentication Library (MSAL) and several transitive dependencies which support authentication for many existing Microsoft PowerShell modules. After this module is imported, you should be able to connect to any Microsoft online service without running into MSAL version conflicts.

docs.title: 📝 Description
docs.text:
Let’s start with a few FAQs:

  • What does DLL Pickle actually do?

DLL Pickle pre-loads the newest version of the MSAL DLLs that may be required by your other installed modules and scripts. (See the example below.)

  • Why does it need to do this?

It is common for PowerShell modules to ship with DLLs that provide precompiled functionality or dependencies. A PowerShell session cannot import two different versions of the same library (DLL). If a module imports one version of a DLL and then a different module attempts to import a second, newer version of that DLL, they will typically see an error that says, “an assembly with the same name is already loaded” and the second module will not be able to authenticate.

  • Why don’t modules use Application Load Context (ALC) to solve this problem?

ALC can be complex to implement and is only available in PowerShell 7, so it is not commonly used in public modules.

  • Do these issues look familiar?
Related GitHub Issues - [Connect-MgGraph fails after Connect-ExchangeOnline](https://github.com/microsoftgraph/msgraph-sdk-powershell/issues/3394) - [UUF Customer feedback: Get-EntraExtensionProperty error](https://github.com/microsoftgraph/entra-powershell/issues/1258) (Assembly with same name is already loaded) - [Assembly with same name is already loaded](https://github.com/microsoftgraph/entra-powershell/issues/1083) - [Design entra-powershell with ALC bridge pattern for a more robust assembly load handling](https://github.com/microsoftgraph/entra-powershell/issues/1242) - [Implement proper assembly isolation to play nice with vscode-powershell](https://github.com/microsoftgraph/msgraph-sdk-powershell/issues/2978) - [Conflict with the .Net dll of the Az module PowerShell/vscode-powershell#3012](https://github.com/PowerShell/vscode-powershell/issues/3012) - [Unable to load Az modules - Assembly with same name is already loaded PowerShell/vscode-powershell#4727](https://github.com/PowerShell/vscode-powershell/issues/4727)

docs.title: 🧑‍💻 An Example Scenario
docs.text:
Numerous PowerShell modules include a dependency on the Microsoft Authentication Library (MSAL) for authenticating to Microsoft’s online services. The latest version of the MSAL is actively maintained in AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-dotnet. However, modules that depend on the MSAL libraries (such as Microsoft.Identity.Client.dll) all update their releases with different versions of MSAL on different schedules. This results in version conflicts that break authentication flows whenever you try to use multiple modules in one session. Examples of modules that can be affected by this include:

  • Az.Accounts
  • ExchangeOnlineManagement
  • Microsoft.Graph.Authentication
  • MicrosoftTeams
  • …and many more.

You could manually attempt to work around this by checking which version of the conflicting DLLs are used by each of your PowerShell modules and then connect first to whichever service module uses the newest version of the DLL. This works because of the “first one wins” rule and because the MSAL is designed to be backwards compatible. DLL Pickle handles this for you by automatically updating and releasing a new version of DLL Pickle whenever a new version of the MSAL is published. As long as you keep the DLL Pickle module up to date and load it first in your PowerShell profile, then all other PowerShell modules should be able to use this new MSAL that is loaded by DLL Pickle.

docs.title: 🥒 Using DLL Pickle
docs.text:
The easiest way to benefit from DLL Pickle is to import the module in your PowerShell profile before any other module or assembly is loaded. Just add the line Import-Module DLLPickle to your profile, save it, and start a new instance of PowerShell.

Alternatively, if you are starting work in a new PowerShell session in which you know you will be authenticating to multiple online services, you can run Import-Module DLLPickle at the beginning of your session and then proceed with connecting to Microsoft’s online services using their first party modules.

docs.title: Versioning
docs.text: This project follows the semantic versioning model. It also packages numerous dependencies that follow their own versioning. To maintain clarity, this project will follow SemVer standards and the following logic for version changes:

docs.title: Major Versions
docs.text: 🏷️ 2.x.x.x - The major version will only change if there is a breaking change in the DLL Pickle project or if an MSAL dependency is released with a new major version (potentially indicating a breaking change).

docs.title: Minor Versions
docs.text:
🏷️ X.1.X.X - The minor version will change if any of the following occur:

  • New features are added to the project
  • New MSAL library dependencies are added to the project
  • A new version of any associated library (DLL) is automatically updated within the project

docs.title: Build Versions
docs.text:
🏷️ X.X.1.X - The build version will change if any of the following occur:

  • Minor refactoring for performance, error handling, or logging
  • Minor fixes for typos or formatting
  • Changes to documentation

docs.title: External Documentation
docs.text:
All libraries tracked for pre-loading by DLL Pickle are maintained and documented by their own code owners. Please see each project accordingly:

  • Microsoft.Identity.Abstractions
  • Microsoft.Identity.Client
  • Microsoft.Identity.Client.Broker
  • Microsoft.Identity.Client.Extensions.Msal
  • Microsoft.Identity.Client.NativeInterop
  • Microsoft.IdentityModel.Abstractions
  • Microsoft.IdentityModel.JsonWebTokens
  • Microsoft.IdentityModel.Logging
  • Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens
  • System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt

docs.title: Description
docs.text: A PowerShell module that helps you get un-stuck from version conflicts that occur when using modules that depend on different versions of the same dependency (such as the Microsoft Authentication Library (MSAL)).

docs.title: Get-DLLsInModulePath
docs.text: Show a list of all DLLs in PowerShell module paths that contain the specified product name in their FileInfo property.

docs.title: Get-ModulesWithDependency
docs.text: Finds installed PowerShell modules that have a common file dependency.

docs.title: Get-ModulesWithVersionSortedIdentityClient
docs.text: Get a list of modules with the MSAL, and which versions each have packaged.

docs.title: Import-DPLibrary
docs.text: Import DLLPickle libraries based on Packages.json configuration.

docs.title: Deep Dive
docs.text: I hope to put this into my own words as I have more time, but for now, here is a podcast-style audio deep dive and a video that explains how DLL Pickle works.

docs.title: Audio Discussion
docs.text: Ending PowerShell DLL Hell: How a Community Fix Uses “First-One-Wins” to Master Azure, Exchange, and Teams Connection Conflicts. An interactive audio deep-dive generated by NotebookLM.

docs.title: Video Explanation
docs.text: A look into a new PowerShell module called DLL Pickle, created to resolve common dependency conflicts experienced when managing multiple Microsoft services. This conflict, known as “DLL Hell” or the “DLL pickle,” occurs because different modules, such as Az.Accounts and ExchangeOnlineManagement, rely on varying versions of the Microsoft Authentication Library (MSAL) and share the “.NET runtime’s ‘first-one-wins’ loading behavior in a single session. The DLL Pickle module functions as a proactive dependency pre-loader by intentionally loading the newest, backward-compatible version of the MSAL DLLs first. By using this technique, which is described as programmatic assembly resolution, the module ensures that all subsequent services use the compatible, latest version of the authentication libraries, preventing session failures caused by incompatible older files. Generated by NotebookLM.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Show a list of all DLLs in PowerShell module paths that contain the specified product name in their FileInfo property.

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text:
Find-DLLInPSModulePath [[-ProductName] <string>] [[-FileName] <string>] [[-Path] <string[]>]
 [[-ExcludeDirectories] <string[]>] [[-Scope] <string>] [-NewestVersion] [-ShowDetails]
 [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Check all installed PowerShell module locations for DLL files that have the specified product name (e.g., ‘Microsoft Identity’) in their file’s ProductName attribute. By default, searches all paths in the PSModulePath environment variable. Can optionally check custom locations using the -Path parameter.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Find-DLLInPSModulePath -ProductName “Microsoft Identity”

Find all DLLs with ‘Microsoft Identity’ in their ProductName property within installed PowerShell module locations.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Find-DLLInPSModulePath -FileName “Microsoft.IdentityModel*.dll”

Find all DLL files matching the pattern ‘Microsoft.IdentityModel*.dll’ that also have ‘Microsoft Identity’ in their ProductName.

Example Output:

InternalName ProductVersion Module ------------ -------------- ------ Microsoft.Identity.Abstractions.dll 9.5.0.0 DLLPickle Microsoft.IdentityModel.Abstractions.dll 0.0.0.0 Az.Accounts Microsoft.IdentityModel.JsonWebTokens.dll 8.6.0.0 ExchangeOnlineManagement Microsoft.IdentityModel.Logging.dll 8.6.0.0 ExchangeOnlineManagement Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols.dll 8.6.1.0 WinTuner Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols.OpenIdConnect.dll 8.6.1.0 WinTuner Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens.dll 8.6.0.0 ExchangeOnlineManagement Microsoft.IdentityModel.Validators.dll 8.6.1.0 WinTuner System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt.dll 8.6.0.0 ExchangeOnlineManagement

Directories to exclude from inspection so the process goes faster.

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Check all installed PowerShell module locations for DLL files that have the specified product name (e.g., ‘Microsoft Identity’) in their file’s ProductName attribute. By default, searches all paths in the PSModulePath environment variable. Can optionally check custom locations using the -Path parameter.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-DLLsInModulePath -ProductName “Microsoft Identity”

Find all Microsoft Identity-related DLLs within installed PowerShell module locations.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-DLLsInModulePath -ProductName “Microsoft Identity” | Sort-Object -Property InternalName | Format-Table InternalName, @{Label = ‘ProductVersion’; Expression = { $.ProductVersionRaw } }, @{Label = ‘Module’; Expression = { $($.FileName -replace ‘^.Modules\/([\/].)?’, ‘$1’) }}

Find all Microsoft Identity-related DLLs within installed PowerShell module locations. Shows the name of the module that the DLL is included in.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Reports the version, path, and scope that would be imported for a given module name.

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text: Get-ModuleImportCandidate [-Name] <string[]> [[-Scope] <string>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Searches PSModulePath in order to determine which version of a module would be imported by Import-Module, mimicking PowerShell’s module resolution logic.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text: Get-ModuleImportCandidate -Name “Pester” Gets the effective module information for Pester from any scope.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text: Get-ModuleImportCandidate “PSReadLine” -Scope CurrentUser Gets the effective module information for PSReadLine only from the CurrentUser scope.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text: “Pester”, “PSReadLine” | Get-ModuleImportCandidate Gets the effective module information for multiple modules from any scope.

docs.title: -Name
docs.text:
The name or array of names of the module to check.

Type: System.String[]
DefaultValue: ''
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: 0
  IsRequired: true
  ValueFromPipeline: true
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: -Scope
docs.text:
Limits the search to modules installed for the CurrentUser, AllUsers, or Any (default) scope.

Type: System.String
DefaultValue: Any
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: 1
  IsRequired: false
  ValueFromPipeline: false
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Evaluates the import order of specified modules based on their versions and the location in PSModulePath.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Get-ModuleImportOrder [[-Name] <String[]>] [-ProgressAction <ActionPreference>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function evaluates the import order of specified modules based on their versions and the location in PSModulePath. It uses Get-ModuleImportCandidate to determine which version of each module would be imported by Import-Module, and then sorts them by the version of ‘Microsoft.Identity.Client.dll’ that is packaged with each module.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-ModuleImportOrder -Name 'Az.Accounts','ExchangeOnlineManagement'

Returns a list of modules ordered by the version of ‘Microsoft.Identity.Client.dll’ they contain.

docs.title: -Name
docs.text:
A list of module names to evaluate for proper import order. Wildcards are allowed.

Type: String[]
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName)
Accept wildcard characters: False

{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Aliases: proga

Required: False
Position: Named
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Finds installed PowerShell modules that have a common file dependency.

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text: Get-ModulesWithDependency [-FileName] <string> [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: ALIASES
docs.text: This cmdlet has the following aliases, {{Insert list of aliases}}

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function queries installed PowerShell resources to identify all modules that have a common dependency on a specific file.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-ModulesWithDependency -FileName ‘Microsoft.Identity.Client.dll’ | Format-Table Name,Version,@{N=’FileName’;E={($_.DependencyPath.Split(‘'))[-1]}},DependencyVersion

This will format the output to show the module name, version, file name, and dependency version in a table.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-ModulesWithDependency -FileName ‘Microsoft.Identity.Client.dll’

This will return an array of PSResourceInfo objects for modules with the specified dependency.

docs.title: -FileName
docs.text:
The name of the file dependency to search for in the module’s manifest file list.

DefaultValue: ''

  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Import DLLPickle dependency libraries.

docs.title: __AllParameterSets
docs.text: Import-DPLibrary [-SkipProblematicAssemblies] [-ShowLoaderExceptions] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text:
Import all DLL files from the appropriate target framework moniker (TFM) directory. DLLs are loaded from the TFM folder based on the PowerShell edition:

  • PowerShell Desktop Edition: bin/net48/
  • PowerShell Core Edition: bin/net8.0/

The latest versions of all dependencies are automatically imported, providing backwards compatibility and avoiding version conflicts.

Some assemblies may have partial compatibility issues in Windows PowerShell due to dependencies on types not available in .NET Framework 4.8. The function will continue loading other assemblies and provide detailed diagnostic information about failures.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Import-DPLibrary

Imports all dependency DLLs from the appropriate TFM directory.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Import-DPLibrary -SkipProblematicAssemblies

Imports compatible DLLs and skips known problematic assemblies in Windows PowerShell.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Import-DPLibrary -ShowLoaderExceptions

Imports DLLs and displays detailed diagnostic information for any failures.

docs.title: -SkipProblematicAssemblies
docs.text:
When running in Windows PowerShell, skip assemblies known to have compatibility issues with .NET Framework 4.8. This prevents warning messages while still loading all compatible dependencies.

Type: System.Management.Automation.SwitchParameter
DefaultValue: False
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: Named
  IsRequired: false
  ValueFromPipeline: false
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: -ShowLoaderExceptions
docs.text:
Display detailed loader exception information when an assembly fails to load. This is useful for diagnosing why specific types within an assembly cannot be loaded.

Type: System.Management.Automation.SwitchParameter
DefaultValue: False
SupportsWildcards: false
Aliases: []
ParameterSets:
- Name: (All)
  Position: Named
  IsRequired: false
  ValueFromPipeline: false
  ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName: false
  ValueFromRemainingArguments: false
DontShow: false
AcceptedValues: []
HelpMessage: ''

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutBuffer, -OutVariable, -PipelineVariable, -ProgressAction, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: System.Management.Automation.PSCustomObject
docs.text:
Returns information about each imported DLL including:

  • DLLName: The name of the DLL file
  • AssemblyName: The assembly name
  • AssemblyVersion: The version of the assembly
  • Status: Import status (Imported, Already Loaded, or Failed)
  • Error: Error message if the import failed

docs.title: NOTES
docs.text:
Known Issues:

  • Microsoft.Identity.Client.dll and System.Diagnostics.DiagnosticSource.dll may fail to load in Windows PowerShell due to dependencies on types not available in .NET Framework 4.8.
  • Use -SkipProblematicAssemblies to avoid warnings for known incompatibilities.
  • Use -ShowLoaderExceptions to get detailed information about why specific types failed to load.

docs.title: about_DLLPickle
docs.text:
ABOUT TOPIC NOTE:
The first header of the about topic should be the topic name.
The second header contains the lookup name used by the help system.

IE:
# Some Help Topic Name
## SomeHelpTopicFileName

This will be transformed into the text file
as `about_SomeHelpTopicFileName`.
Do not include file extensions.
The second header should have no spaces.
